 8         This case concerns regulations promulgated under the Patient Protection

 9   and Affordable Care Act of 2010 (the “ACA”), Pub. L. No. 111-148, 124 Stat. 119.

10   The ACA generally requires employers with fifty or more full-time employees to

11   offer “a group health plan or group health insurance coverage” that provides

12   “minimum essential coverage.” 26 U.S.C. § 5000A(f)(2); id. § 4980H(a)(1), (c)(2).

13   Unless an exception applies, as part of this minimal essential coverage, the ACA

14   requires an employer’s group health plan or group health insurance coverage to

16   sharing requirements.” 42 U.S.C. § 300gg-13(a)(4). Without “cost sharing

 4         “We review de novo a district court’s grant of summary judgment.” Byrne v.

10   court’s treatment of cross-motions for summary judgment we “evaluate each

14         I. The Religious Freedom Restoration Act

15         Under the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment, the government

16   may not “prohibit[] the free exercise” of religion. U.S. Const. amend. I. In 1990,

17   the Supreme Court clarified its Free Exercise Clause jurisprudence by holding

18   that the government need not have a compelling governmental interest in order


                                               19

 3   (1990). While consistent with much of the Supreme Court’s prior free exercise

 4   precedent, Smith was arguably in tension with two prior Supreme Court cases,

 5   both of which the Smith Court declined to overrule. Id. at 881–85. In these cases,

 6   the Court used strict-scrutiny like analysis and asked whether the challenged law

 7   substantially burdened a religious practice and, if it did, whether that burden

 8   was justified by a compelling governmental interest. See Wisconsin v. Yoder, 406

 9   U.S. 205, 220–21 (1972); Sherbert v. Verner, 374 U.S. 398, 405–06 (1963).

10         In response to Smith, Congress enacted RFRA, which provides in relevant

11   part that the “[g]overnment may substantially burden a person’s exercise of

13   in furtherance of a compelling governmental interest” and “is the least restrictive

16   enacting RFRA, Congress “intended to ‘restore the compelling interest test as set
